div.p:
Iam nunc accedamus Lombardus, I, d. 17, c. 1, n. 1 . After the Master determined about the visible mission of the Holy Spirit, now he makes a determination about the invisible mission. And this is divided into three parts. I say this because in the first he posits his intention about charity and delight, in the second place he shows how charity receives augmentation or intension, in the third place he brings up the opposite opinion with its support. The second begins at
hic quaeritur si caritas Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 17, c. 5 [n. 1] . The third at
supra dictum est quod Spiritus Sanctus Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 17, c. 6 [n. 1] .

The first part which is the principal part of the present lecture is divided into three parts because in the first place the Master asserts his opinion, in the second place he adds a conformation to his opinion, and in the third place he adds a response, some quibbling. The second starts at
ne autem in re tanta Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 17, c. 1 [n. 3] . The third at
sed ne forte Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 17, c. 3 [n. 1] .

Whether personal love of the divine essence is formal love of a created power? Whether the immense gift is the formal love by which the real one loving rightly loves the highest good? Whether the highest love of the Holy Spirit produced through two spirators is that by which we are formally lovers of the highest good, justice, and truth?

That this is not the case is argued in the first place because created charity wit the will sufficiently produce some meritorious act, therefore positing that the Holy Spirit is formally that by which the mind loves and earns merit strays from the truth. The consequence is valid and the antecedent seems to come from the mind of the
Apostle in I Corinthians 15
who says,
I have worked hard than all of them, but not I, but the grace of God with me
I Corinthians 15:10 .

In the second place, only charity
divides among the sons of the kingdom and perdition
Augustine, De Trinitate, XV, 18, 32 (CCL 50A, 507) , as says Augustine XV De Trinitate, in chapter 18 . But this love is not the highest personal love or the Holy Spirit, as Our Gregory says is clear from the text of dicit patere ex textu I Corinthians 13, where it says
if I speak with tongues of men and of angels
I Ad Corinthios 13:1
etc. Again Romans 5
the charity of God is diffused in your hearts
Romans 5:5

In the third place, nothing immeasurable is able to be the intrinsic form of something measured, therefore. The consequence is valid. The antecedent is proved because subjective inherence is repugnant to the unmeasured. In the second place because the measured then would have unmeasured justice formally, which is repugnant, therefore.

In opposition, it is argued that the highest love alone is able to sufficiently justify the created mind and to actuate for ordinate loving, therefore the question is true. The consequence is good, and the antecedent is clear because the Holy Spirit is able to be communicated to the created mind without incomplex created gifts,
as is proved above Vide supra .

First conclusion: that created love is habit supernaturally infused to the mind since God actuating the mind in a special way and is making God beloved to the mind through the divine acceptance actually or habitually since he is partially causing some merit of the mind This is proven in the first place that the habit is supernaturally infused. This is clear from
Extra, de haereticis in clementinis Extra, XXX . In the second place, that it from God that the mind etc., is clear because God is the life of the soul, therefore he actuates it in its spiritual being. The consequence is valid. The antecedent is from
Gregory Super Ezechialem,
in the second part of his fifth homily
Gregorius Magnus, Super Ezechialem . In the third place, because he makes the mind pleasing. This is clear through the word of Christ
I know my sheep John 10:27
or
I know whom I have chosen John 13:18 . Item, John 13
he loved them to the end John 13:1 . But that charity makes God beloved to the mind is clear though
Augustine in Moribus ecclesiae, in chapter 14
through love, he says, it happens that we formed to God
Augustine, Moribus Ecclesiae, c. 14 . Again
De doctrina christiana
he calls love the motion of the soul
Augustinus, De Doctrina Christiana, 3, 10 . Again in the book of the Confessions
my weight is my love by which
Augustinus, Confessionum, 13, 9, 10
etc. The fourth part is clear from the above.

The first corollary: it stands that charity actually informs the mind and the same mind does not actually incline, in opposition to the opinion of
Hugolino, in distinction 17 or 14 Hugolinus, XXX . It is clear that created charity does not inclind unless moved by the Holy Spirit since this is its instrument and also according to itself. Whence he says that in meritorious work uncreated charity unifies, inclines, and operates, but only the potency or will operates, and the Holy Spirit does not move actually unless when it wishes the mind to act, as is clear in
the first book of Ezekiel , where it says
where the impulse of the spirit was, that is where they went Ezekiel 1:12 .

Second corollary: the one having the habit of charity is not able to go out into its proper act unless the Holy Spirit actuates and moves the created will. This is clear through
Augustine, in his book, the sermon on the words of the lord, etc.
where he says that ubi dicit quod
the good which makes man good in nothing other than God, for one does restore a good man unless that person is always good
Augustinus, XXX , against the position of
Henry of Ghent Henry of Ghent, XXX .

Third corollary: love does not only produce merit with respect to some intension and grade, but also with respect to substance and act. This is clear from the last two parts of the conclusion which indeed with this corollary are proved by the saying of the Apostoli alleged above for the first argument
laboravi I Corinthians 15:10
etc.

Second conclusion: meritorious action of eternal life inasmuch as it is of this type proceeds formally and effectively from the grace of eternal predestination This is proved because ratio of divine acceptance of any type of good operation corresponds to this kind of grace alone, therefore. In the second place, because this alone renders the mind worthy for eternal life, therefore. In the third place, it is proved through
Augustine, in his book De haeresibus, in chapter 8 Augustine, XXX , where he shows that through this alone is one able to fulfill the divine command, therefore.

First corollary: it is possible that an act is accepted by God and no infused habit is in the mind, against
Scotus, in this distinction 17, question 2 Scotus, I, d. 17, q. 2 , because only the grace of predestination is a means suitable for making a good act accepted by God and to be meritorious of eternal life as the conclusion states.

Second corollary: though every meritorious act is produced freely by a created will, nevertheless for someting to a meritorious act is not in the power of human beings alone because it is not in their power that such an act is accepted by God, therefore. This is confirmed because then the acts of the blessed would meritorious just as those of the pilgrim. The consequence is clear because every causality which the blessed had in this life with respect to a good act, they also have in heaven, they cause more perfectly, therefore this corollary is in opposition to Scotus where noted above.

The third corollary: it is not the case that some numbered among the damned had every merited the prize of those being saved. This is clear because no act of foreknowledge proceeds from the grace of predestination, therefore no such thing is meritorious of eternal life. The consequences is clear from the conclusion from which it is able to be elicited that just as it is impossible that being saved is foreknown, so it is impossible that a life is foreknown to merit or have merited eternal life.

Third conclusion: personal love of the divine essence is a vital form of the created power elevating and actuating in some good doing. This is proved through the saying of the Apostle
love of God is diffuse Romanos 5:5
etc. which
Augustine Augustine, xxx
explains is about uncreated charity. Again, in Romans
For the spirit gives testimony to our spirit that we are sons of God
Romans 8:16
et ibidem
whoever are led by the Spirit of God, they are the sons of God
Romans 8:14 , where the Apostle speaks notionally in the spirit and not through the Holy Spirit.

For the third question there are the words of
Augustine XV De Trinitate, in chapter 5, de parvis
love which is from God and is God is properly the Holy Spirit
through which charity is diffused in our hearts through which total charity dwells in us
Augustinus, De Trinitate, XV, c. 5 , and there he says more things related to what we have proposed.

The first corollary: something is the form of another thing elicitively or actuatively and to the same thing it is not in it constitutively, inhaesively, or informatively, against
Fastinugs, in book 3, question 2
Fastinus de Asti, III, q. 2 . This is clear because that it is able to be communicated to itself intrinsically, representatively, exemplarily, immutatively, causally, and elevatively, supernaturally, just as
Lord Jacob of Viterbo deduces in his Quodlibetis
Iacobus de Viterbo, Qudodlibet, xxx .

The second corollary: the Holy Spirit or the highest personal love is the efficient formal ratio by which, through which, and on account of which the act of ordinate love is elicited, in opposition to
Gregory, in book 1, distinction 17, question 1, article 1, near the end Gregorius Ariminiensis, I, d. 17, q. 1, a. 1, . This is clear because otherwise while the Holy Spirit is formally and intrinsically actuating it would be possible for the mind to be elevated to gratuitous being, which is false. This is confirmed because the Holy Spirit is personally intrinsic to the mind without its own gifts with such and interaction which would suffice from gratituous being. This is clear from what has been said, and just he himself also concedes in
in that distinction, article 2 XXX, I, d. 17, a. 2 . Again, if the Holy Spirit were given to the created mind without its own incomplex created gifts, it would not be otherwise united to it in this case than it is now, but in that the mind would love in the Holy Spirit, through the Holy Spirit, and on account of the Holy Spirit, therefore it loves just as now give that it loves ordinately. This is clear through
the same person, in book 1, distinction 14
XXX, I, d. 14

Third corollary: created love of the mind which is elevative into God is the same as the grace that gratifying the mind, against
Saint Thomas, first part of the second part, question 2, article 3
Thomas Aquinas, S.T., I-IIae, q. 2, a. 3 , and against
Thomas of Strasbourg, in distinction 17 of books 1, question 1, article 4
Thomas de Argentina, I, d. 17, q. 1, a. 4 . THe corollary is clear because both the Apostle and Augustine indifferently exchange one for the other and use them to mean the same thing in diverse places. This is confirmed because otherwise it would be the case that the mind is acceptable to God but not beloved or vice versa, which does not seem to be possible.

From what has been said affirmative part of the title is clear, namely that personal love etc., for in the specified mode it is the form forming, causing, and supernaturally elevating the mind, nevertheless it is not the form inhering or composing.

div.head: Obiectiones et responsiones
div.p: Contra primam conclusione et primum corollarium: caritas creata est pondus animae ut patet per dictam, sed pondus semper actualiter praemit et gravat illud cui Magister, ergo caritas semper actualiter movet et incinat potentiam in qua est ad bene agendum.

Secundo, contra secundam corollarium: habens Spiritum Sanctum non indiget speciali motione Spiritus Sancti se habens caritatem habet Spiritum Sanctum, ergo. Maior nota. Minor probatur per illud Apostoli
gratia Dei seu caritas diffusa est Romanos 5:5
etc.

Tertio, contra tertium corollarium: si caritas efficit actionem meritoriam cum voluntate vel posterius, et hoc non per
Anselmus Monologion 5 Anselmus, Monologion, 5, xxx
ubi comparat gratiam sessori et voluntatem iumento vel prius. Et hoc non quia tunc habitus utentur potentia contra rationem habitus quia potentia debet uti habitu vel aeque primo producerent. Et hoc non cum sint partiales causae et aequivoce differentes specie, ergo caritas nullo modo concurrit effective. Patet haec consequentia sufficienti divisione[?]

Contra secundam conclusione et eius corollaria, sequeretur quod Deus haberet aliam volitionem secundum rationem de aliquo oso ipso in nullo vari?to. Consequens falsum et consequentia probatur quia peccator ante praemiam est indignus vita aeterna, ergo non est acceptus ad vitam aeternam et post poenitentiam est dignus et acceptus, ergo
vel
vel
per aliquod inhaerens. Et si sic, haberetur contra conclusionem quia oportebit ponere formam creatam vel per nihil. Et si sic, haberetur consequentia probata quod nulla mutatione facta in mente Deus habebit respectu eius volitionem animam quam prius.

Secundo, si Deus acceptaret poenitentem ad vitam aeternam vel est velle beatificante voluntate beneplaciti pro tunc, et hoc non quia tunc statim beatificaret vel est velle istum secundum
dispositionem quam nunc habet esse dignum tali praemio quali non voluit prius esse dignum sed talis diversitas non potest poni in divina voluntate nisi propter diversitatem creaturae vel propter alium et alium modum essendi creaturae.

Tertio, volitio divina cum sit unus actus in se non habet rationem oppositorum actuum vel velle et nolle absque distinctione obiectorum, ergo cum Deus vellit iustificatum acceptare ad aliquid quoddam non vult peccatorem, sequitur quod haec distinctio voluntatis divinae necessario requirat distinctionem actualem ex parte obiectorum, ergo aliter se habet iustificatus quam non iustificatus et non nisi per gratiam creatam, ergo.

Contra tertiam conclusionem quia illa videtur esse
opinio Magistri in hac distinctione 17 Lombard, I, d. 17, xxx
quae non tenetur ad quam plura inconvenientia sequuntur, nam ad hoc sequitur quod actus caritatis non erit meritorius, secundo quod non voluntarius, tertio quod non esset delectibilis, quarto quod actus sit Spiritus Sanctus, quinto quod homo mereretur ex puris naturalibus, sexto quod Spiritus Sanctus in actu dilectionis uniretur suppositionaliter naturae rationali quae omnia sunt falsa.

Contra primum corollarium quia cum forma non sit remissius forma ei quod informat quam sit formam in sui natura, sequitur quod Spiritus Sanctus esset menti immensa et immensa forma, et per consequens immensa iustitia et sic salus Dei et hominis non erit alia et alia contra
Beatum Augustinum De quaestionibus novi et veteris testamenti Augustinus, De quaestionibus novi et veteris, xxx

Tertio, contra tertium corollarium: potest argui
ex dictis Gregorii ubi supra primo Gregorius Ariminiensis, XXX
quia Apostolus loquitur uniformiter de caritate et aliis habitibus.

Secundo per
Beatum Augustinum homelia supra canonica Iohannis
exponentem illud Ad Romanos 8
ipse spiritus postulat pro nobis Romanos 8:26
etc. quid inquit Augustinus
ipse Spiritus Sanctus interpellat pro sanctis[?] natura ipsa caritas quae in te per Spiritum Sanctum facta Augustinus, XXX , ergo illa caritas non est Spiritus Sanctus aliter diceretur factus quod est falsum.

Contra tertium corollarium, substantia caritatis et gratiae sunt diversa, ergo sunt habitus distincti. Consequentia tenet et antecedens probatur quia immediatum subiectum gratiae est substantia animae subiectum vero caritatis creatae est voluntas, igitur. Haec est
ratio Thomae de Argentis Thomas de Argentina, xxx .

Ad primum, dicitur quod pondus semper actu vel habitu inclinat, et sic videtur Augustinus intellexisse dicens
eo feror quocumque feror Augustinus, Confessionum, XIII, 9, 10
eo feror nec est simile de ponderibus rerum naturalium gravium quia caritas est pondus supernaturale quod actualiter inclinat tantum quantum Spiritus Sanctus vult ipsam inclinare et agere.

Ad secundum in maiori, dicitur quod Spiritus Sanctus potest haberi gratificative et habitualiter quasi non, tamen dico per modum habitus et potest haberi motive actualiter. Primo modo negatur maior. Secundo modo conceditur tota ratio quia de illa motione et habitione loquor in conclusione.

Ad tertium, primo dicitur quod si talis actus consideratur ut actus, sic est principaliter a Deo et quasi aeque primo a gratia et voluntate. Si consideretur ut est liber, sic est primo a Deo, secundo a gratia, et tertio a voluntate. Si ut meritorius, sic dicit
Hugolinus Hugolinus, XXX
quod nec gratia nec voluntas habent latitudinem aliquam effectivam respectu illius, sed
Scotus in distinctione 17 Scotus, I, d. 17
dicit quod sic est principaliter a Deo, secundo a gratia, tertio a voluntate, sed Scotus in responsione praedicta Hugolini quam ponit
libro secundo circa distinctionem 27 Scotus, II, d. 27
quia reputo illam bonam.

Ad primum contra secundam conclusionem, dico quod omnes illae rationes tres fundantur super falso, scilicet quod praedestinatus existens in peccato mortali non sit Deo acceptus et postea sit acceptus quod non concedo. Immo dico quod praedestinatus quantumcumque peccator semper est et ab aeterno fuit acceptus Deo ad vitam aeternam habendam, et hoc etiam habet dicere
Doctor Subtilis Scotus, XXX
contra quem ponuntur illa corollaria, ut patet in secunda quaestione sua gratia eandem distinctionem, ipse tamen in eadem distinctione ponit triplicem acceptationem. Prima est simplex complacentia qua Deus acceptat omnem rem possibilem vel futuram. Secunda est efficax et illa est qua vult rem esse in effectu et media necessario requisita ad eam et sic acceptat omne existens. Tertia est quaedam specialis acceptatio quae est ordinativa volitio ad votum ut consequatur aliquid maius et hoc completive et de hac loquitur non autem de aliis, ut patet ex suis dictis.

Ad primum contra tertiam conclusionem, dicitur quod secundum expositionem secundum quam communiter exponitur opinio Magistri illud est falsum quia conclusio mea non negat habitum creatum caritatis nec ponit Spiritum Sanctum est caritatem menti informative inhaerente sed intrinsece et actuative, utrum autem Magister habitum creatum negaverit dicit Scotus, etiam Thomas de Argentia quod non, sicut patet
distinctione 3a primi Scotus, XXX, I, d. 3; Thamas de Argentina, XXX, I, d. 3 et
26 secundi libri Scotus XXX, II, d. 26; Thamas de Argentina, XXX, II, d. 26 . Secundo, dico quod illa inconvenientia illata non sequuntur ex dictis Magistri probat de tribus prius ostendit
aegidius noster in hac distinctione, parte prima, quaestione secunda Aegidius Romanos, I, d. 17, pars 1, q. 2 . De aliis tribus ostendit
Thomas de Argentia in eadem distinctione, quaestione prima, articulo Thomas de Argentina, I, d. 17, q. 1, a. XX
ubi, vide eius responsiones et rationes probantes habitum caritatis causatae non esse in veritate.

Ad secundum dicitur quod antecedens est verum de forma constitutiva intrinseca vel informativa, non autem Spiritus Sanctus est taliter menti forma intrinseca quia Spiritus Sanctus non inhaeret menti. Et dico ultra quod per Spiritum Sanctum mens intrinsece non est iusta. Tertio dico quod potest concedi quod non est alia Dei salus et alia hominis salus, licet aliter sit Dei salus et aliter hominis.

Ad tertium, dico quod non semper Apostolus loquitur conformiter, ut patet ex dictis Augustini in tertia conclusione addutis ad auctoritatem Augustini dicentis
quid est spiritus sanctus nisi ipsa caritas vitae per spiritum sanctum focam Augustinus, xxx . Dico primo quod auctoritas in forma est contra Gregorium Nostrum et pro Magistro quia Augustinus dicit
nihil est Spiritus Sanctus nisi ipsa caritas vitae
Augustinus, XXX . Secundo dico quod non dicit quod Spiritus Sanctus sit factus vel quod caritas sit facta simpliciter sed quod
facta
perfacta facta
est caritas vel quod Spiritus Sanctus factus est in mente quia incepit esse caritas in mente et incepit esse in mente sicut Deus incepit esse in mundo, tamen Deus numquam incepit esse multum ergo refert dicere Spiritus Sanctus est facta caritas et dicere caritas facta est in te vel Spiritus Sanctus factus est caritas in te quia secunda est vera et prima falsa.

Ad quartum, negatur antecedens quia voluntas non distinguitur ab essentia animae saltem realiter. Secundo dico quod consequentia non valet etiam apud Thomam de Argentia quia ipse habet concedere quod aliquod accidens potest habere plura subiecta, et tamen erunt unum numero quia secundum eum subiectum immediatum accidentium est ipsa quantitas et subiectum principale est substantia, et illa intellectus se distinguitur sic similiter posito quod voluntas distingueretur ab anima ad hoc voluntas potest esse subiectum immediatum gratiae et essentia animae subiectum principale et sic posset nuncupari utroque nomine. Ad rationes in oppositum patet ex dictis.

div.head: Conclusiones
div.p: Iam nunc accedamus Lombardus, I, d. 17, c. 1, n. 1 . Prima conclusio: quod Spiritus Sanctus quid Deus est ac tertia intrinsece persona a Patre et Filio ac a se ipso temporaliter procedit seu mittitur fidelibus ac donatur.

Secunda conclusio: quod Spiritus Sanctus est amor seu caritas qua nos diligimus Deum et proximum quae caritas est ita in nobis ut faciat diligere nos Deum et proximum, tunc Spiritus Sanctus dicitur mitti vel dari nobis et qui diligit ipsam
dilectionem qua diligit proximum diligit Deum quia ipsa dilectio Dei Spiritus Sanctus est ut probat auctoritatibus Augustini.
Tertia conclusio: quod Spiritus Sanctus est amor Patris et Filii quo se invicem amant et nos.

Quarta conclusio: quod Deus dicitur spes nostra et patiam nostra non quod ipse Deus sit ista, sed quia ista sunt, non tamen Deus dicitur caritas illo modo qui ipse est caritas, ipsa potest ergo dici quod Deus seu Spiritus Sanctus est caritas qui diligimus Deum ut ille ablativus qua dicit habitudinem causae efficientis et formalis non perficientis et inhaerentis sed exemplantis et elevantis sequitur distinctionis huius secunda pars.
